March 16, 2020: Edition #1 (Short Novels in a Very Specific Place)

Our first (very specific) #gmgreads theme: Short novels about being in a very specific place‚Äîand tonight I‚Äôll start with my own local indies in Vermont, Phoenix Books and NorthShire Bookstore.

1) Olga Grushin‚Äôs amazing THE LINE, a book about the very specific Russian practice of waiting in line, for who knows how long for something that may never happen.

2) Howard Norman‚Äôs THE MUSEUM GUARD, a small book about the life of a museum and the paintings on its wall that transform lives.

3) Robin Sloan‚Äôs magical MR. PENUMBRA‚Äôs 24-HOUR BOOKSTORE, about the oddest bookstore of all‚Äîand the quest to understand what it‚Äôs really selling.

4) Justin Cronin‚Äôs THE SUMMER GUEST‚Äîone of my favorite books of all time‚Äîabout a dying man and his fishing camp in Maine.

5) And then my very favorite novel about a very specific place: Calvin Trillin‚Äôs hilarious TEPPER ISN‚ÄôT GOING OUT, about a man and his parking space. If you need a hilarious read, grab this. I dare you not to read it in a single sitting.

March 17, 2020: Edition #2 (Biographies About People You Wish You Knew)

I love reading biographies of people I know either little or nothing about and then being wowed by the lives they lived, so tonight‚Äôs theme is ‚Äúbiographies about people you‚Äôll wish you knew,‚Äù all for sale through my old indie DC haunt Politics & Prose.

1) Jason Fagone‚Äôs biography, THE WOMAN WHO SMASHED CODES, about Elizabeth Friedman, America‚Äôs original and most bad-ass codebreaker, made me green with envy as a writer.

2) Samantha Power‚Äôs biography of Sergio Vieira de Mello, the UN enjoy killed in the Baghdad embassy bombing, is IMHO her greatest book, and one that changed the way that I look at power and the world (and it‚Äôs soon to be a Netflix movie).

3) Alexander Stille‚Äôs biography EXCELLENT CADAVERS, about two mafia-fighting Italian magistrates, Giovanni Falcone and Paolo Borsellino, is a testament to the power of the human spirit and the importance of the rule of law.

4) Scott Anderson‚Äôs biography, THE MAN WHO TRIED TO SAVE THE WORLD, about a swashbuckling Texan, Fred Cuny, who became the world‚Äôs ‚ÄúMaster of Disaster‚Äù is an incredible tale with a puzzle of an ending.

5) I‚Äôve read a lot about 9/11 in recent years, and no biography stuck with me like HEART OF A SOLDIER, about Rick Rescorla, a Vietnam vet-turned-British paratrooper-turned-Morgan Stanley‚Äôs security director whose dedication on 9/11 saved hundreds of lives.

March 18, 2020: Edition #3 (Fascinating Professional Memoirs)

Tonight‚Äôs theme is ‚Äúfascinating professional memoirs,‚Äù well-written books about people‚Äôs unique jobs and experiences that teach you about a world you didn‚Äôt know, all for sale through the legendary Powells, which today more than any day needs every ounce of help it can get.

1) You‚Äôve probably seen or heard about Anna Weiner‚Äôs new memoir, UNCANNY VALLEY, about working in tech‚Äîit‚Äôs wonderfully written and its insights are incisive. This was the most fun book I‚Äôve read in a long time.

2) Edward Conlon‚Äôs richly detailed BLUE BLOOD is about his time as a cop in the NYPD and is the best cop memoir I‚Äôve ever come across.

3) I‚Äôve read two remarkable memoirs of being a firefighter, Zac Unger‚Äôs WORKING FIRE about being an Oakland firefighter and Jason Ramos‚Äô SMOKEJUMPER, about being an elite wildland firefighter.

4) Salman Rushie‚Äôs memoir JOSEPH ANTON, about his time in hiding, while facing an assassination fatwa from Iran, is remarkable‚Äîand an incredible journey through what a life in hiding is like.

5) If you‚Äôve never read it, Ruth Reichl‚Äôs memoir of her time as the NYT food critic, GARLIC & SAPPHIRES, is both charming and insightful about the business of food writing.

March 19, 2020: Edition #4 (Great Books About Hard Times)

This is a hard time for the US‚Äîbut America has weathered a lot of hard times and many Americans face challenges on a daily basis. Tonight‚Äôs theme is great books about hard times, and tonight‚Äôs indie is Raven Book Store in Lawrence, KS, which is offering $1 ‚Äúpandemic shipping.‚Äù

1) Isabel Wilkerson‚Äôs A WARMTH OF OTHER SUNS, about black Americans‚Äô search for freedom during the Great Migration, an incredible chapter of American history I knew little about.

2) Timothy Egan‚Äôs THE WORST HARD TIME is an epic book about the Dust Bowl and the hard lives of the Depression, the real-life version of Steinbeck‚Äôs great tales.

3) Two about the challenges of everyday poverty: Adrian Nicole LeBlanc‚Äôs RANDOM FAMILY, the most unrelenting book I‚Äôve ever read, and Jason DeParle‚Äôs AMERICAN DREAM, which will change the way you think about welfare.

3A) Also don‚Äôt miss Matthew Desmond‚Äôs EVICTED, about the challenges of housing in America.

4) And then two classic books about the opioid crisis: DREAMLAND by Sam Quinones and and Beth Macy‚Äôs DOPESICK.

5) Lastly, a much more uplifting book about America rising: James and Deb Fallows‚Äô fascinating and inspiring book, OUR TOWN, about what truly makes America great and how cities and towns are adapting to new realities.

March 20, 2020: Edition #5 (On Writing and Editing)

Tonight‚Äôs theme is great books about writing and editing‚Äîthe books that have inspired me and taught me a lot about what makes smart writing‚Äîand tonight‚Äôs indie is Emma Straub‚Äôs Brooklyn Books Are Magic, which is offering 99 cent shipping.

1) My favorite writerly biography is A. Scott Berg‚Äôs EDITOR OF GENIUS, about Max Perkins, the Scriber Books editor who brought us Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Thomas Wolfe, Marguerite Young, and more.

2) When I was an editor, I kept a shelf of copies of Anne Lamott‚Äôs BIRD BY BIRD to hand out to writers and visitors. It is packed with wonderful, meaningful advice about writing & life. I think of this book and its advice probably every week.

3) Stephen King‚Äôs ON WRITING is a must-read, even as someone who has literally never read a single one of his books.

4) The collection of Marjorie Williams‚Äô work, WOMAN AT THE WASHINGTON ZOO, is as perfect a collection of essays and profile as has ever been assembled.

5) Thomas Kunkel‚Äôs biography of the New Yorker‚Äôs visionary editor, Harold Ross, GENIUS IN DISGUISE, is a great, fun tale of what makes an editor masterful.

March 21, 2020: Edition #6 (Short Novels)

For years, I used to give one small novel for Christmas gifts every year to close friends‚Äîoften a translation or novella, but always a book to be consumed in a single sitting or afternoon. Here are five of my favorite short novels, and tonight‚Äôs indie is Strand Book Store.

1) Gregoire Bouillier‚Äôs MYSTERY GUEST, about a man inexplicably invited to a party five years later by an ex.

2) Julian Barnes‚Äô SENSE OF AN ENDING, about a man considering his legacy.

3) Adolfo Bioy Casares‚Äô THE INVENTION OF MOREL, the transfixing basis for the movie ‚ÄúLast Year in Marienbad.‚Äù

4) My college friend Ceridwen Dovey wrote an evocative book, BLOOD KIN, about four people caught in the aftermath of a coup.

5) Denis Johnson‚Äôs TRAIN DREAMS manages to pack an epic tale of the west into a novella‚Äôs 116 pages.

March 22, 2020: Edition #7 (Fascinating Subcultures)

I just read Joe Posnanski‚Äòs new book, THE LIFE AND AFTERLIFE OF HARRY HOUDINI, a delightful romp through the world of magic, so tonight‚Äôs theme is books on fascinating Christopher Guest-esque subcultures. Our indie tonight is Wellesley Books.

1) Colson Whitehead‚Äôs charming book NOBLE HUSTLE, and his own tour through the strange world of high-stakes poker championships.

2) Joshua Foer went deep inside the world of memory and accidentally became the national memory champion along the way in MOONWALKING WITH EINSTEIN.

3) There are two books about the subculture of Civil War buffs, Andrew Ferguson‚Äîwho has to be one of the nation‚Äôs most entertaining writers‚Äîpenned LAND OF LINCOLNS and Tony Horwitz‚Äôs classic CONFEDERATES IN THE ATTIC.

4) Jane Kramer wrote a great book in the 1990s, LONE PATRIOT, about the world of anti-government militias, a movement that‚Äôs just as relevant today as ever.

5) Lastly, Ted Conover has done some amazing immersive reporting‚Äîincluding his book on being a prison guard at Sing Sing, NEWJACK and his book about riding the rails with America‚Äôs hoboes.

March 23, 2020: Edition #8 (Food Books)

We had takeout for dinner tonight (hi and thanks @henwoodvt1!), and I feel fully rejuvenated and reenergized, a reminder of how food can give not just physical nourishment but spiritual as well. So let‚Äôs talk tonight about favorite food books, and celebrate Harvard Books.

1) Legit one of the most important books of my life, one that changed the way I approach every meal everyday, is Tyler Cowen‚Äôs AN ECONOMIST GETS LUNCH, about how to think of eating and especially meals out at restaurants (ha!) differently.

2) Two great memoirs by acclaimed food writers, Ruth Reichl‚Äôs (@ruthreichl) TENDER AT THE BONE, and Jeffrey Steingarten‚Äôs THE MAN WHO ATE EVERYTHING.

3) Barbara Kingsolver‚Äôs ANIMAL VEGETABLE MIRACLE would be an especially delicious book to read right now and celebrate the changing of the seasons.

4) My friend Eric Felten has written one of most fascinating (and tasty!) histories of cocktails and drinking in America, HOW‚ÄôS YOUR DRINK? Lastly, two great books by roving gourmands, Jim Harrison wrote an all-time favorite, THE RAW AND THE COOKED and famed political writer RW Apple was also an incredible food writer, as evidenced by FAR FLUNG AND WELL FED.

March 24, 2020: Edition #9 (Epic, Sweeping Novels)

So we‚Äôre now into week two of something that will last somewhere between 14 days and forever. It really feels like we‚Äôre living in an epic story, where we don‚Äôt know how the story ends here. Tonight‚Äôs theme is just that: epic, sweeping novels.

1) Don Winslow‚Äôs (@donwinslow) THE CARTEL is just a fabulous big book, packed with everything one could want in a good story.

2) Two great works of multi-generation history are Philip Meyer‚Äôs THE SON, a story of a young Texan and the Comanche, one of most evocative books I‚Äôve ever come across, and Kurt Andersen‚Äôs (@KBAndersen) HEYDAY is a delicious read.

3) Two incredible epics of Vietnam that will make you feel the tension, the jungle, and everything about that war: Denis Johnson‚Äôs TREE OF SMOKE and Karl Marlantes‚Äô MATTERHORN.

4) I wasn‚Äôt sure whether I liked Richard Ford‚Äôs CANADA until I reached the very final page, a page that shaped my whole philosophy about life.

5) Lastly, this is sort of a cheat, but when you‚Äôre talking about books that pack a ton of history and life into it, it‚Äôs hard to find a nonfiction example better than Laura Hillenbrand‚Äôs UNBROKEN.

March 25, 2020: Edition #10 (Investigative Biographies)

I‚Äôm hoping over the quarantine to read George Packer‚Äôs OUR MAN, about Richard Holbrooke, and I love what I‚Äôd call ‚Äúinvestigative biographies,‚Äù books that mix the writer and the quest to understand a subject. So here are my favorites, with my hometown indie Bear Pond Books.

1) Anyone who hasn‚Äôt read Casey Cep‚Äôs (@cncep) FURIOUS HOURS, about Harper Lee and the murder case she hoped would be her own IN COLD BLOOD, please drop everything you‚Äôre doing and go get it.

2) RANGER GAMES, by Ben Blum (@benzblum), didn‚Äôt get a lot of attention when it came out, but it was an excellent read‚Äîa tale of how a family member ended up in the midst of a bank robbery.

3) Kai Bird (@kaibird123) wrote an amazing biography, THE GOOD SPY, about one of the most important-and-least known US intelligence operatives of the last half century, Robert Ames, who was killed in the Beirut embassy bombing.

4) Shane Harris‚Äô (@shaneharris) THE WATCHERS is a great tale of the rise of American surveillance and the career of Admiral John Poindexter.

5) I thought Matt Bai‚Äôs (@mattbai) ALL THE TRUTH IS OUT was one of the best books on politics of the last decade, tracing a direct line from Gary Hart to our modern circus. It really made me think about what the modern media has wrought.

March 26, 2020: Edition #11 (Foreign Lands)

Every night all this strangeness continues, it seems like we‚Äôre increasingly venturing in bizarre, foreign territory‚Äîso tonight‚Äôs theme are some of my favorite novels about far-off foreign lands, both literal and figurative.

1) David Mitchell‚Äôs THE THOUSAND AUTUMNS OF JACOB DE ZOET is a tale of going to the end of the earth in the 1800s, a story of a Dutchman in the trading city of Nagasaki.

2) Mohsin Hamid‚Äôs EXIT WEST is just one of the best books I‚Äôve ever read, hands down, full stop, a story of emigration and displacement.

3) Tomas Eloy Martinez‚Äôs TANGO SINGER, a novel of magical realism set in Argentina (obviously!) mixes Borges and opera in the hunt for a singer rumored to be better than Carlos Gardel.

4) Ann Patchett‚Äôs BEL CANTO is the story of a South American hostage crisis and the relationships between the terrorists and their hostages.

5) Evelyn Waugh‚Äôs SCOOP is one of the great journalism novels of all time (and the first novel I really read as an adult) about foreign correspondents competing in the golden age of journalism.

March 27, 2020: Edition #12 (Fun to Read)

At the request of @BetsOnTech, tonight‚Äôs theme is simply books that are just fun to read‚Äînot heavy, not big, not dark, just fun. Here are some of my favorites.

1) Brock Clarke‚Äôs book title is pretty self-explanatory, AN ARSONIST‚ÄôS GUIDE TO WRITERS‚Äô HOMES IN NEW ENGLAND, and it‚Äôs exactly as enjoyable as you‚Äôd think it would be.

2) Two fun satires-of-sorts, Robert Littell‚Äôs tough-to-find DEBRIEFING, about the oddities of intelligence: and Joshua Ferris‚Äôs THEN WE CAME TO THE END, about a place we used to go called the ‚Äúoffice.‚Äù

3) German defense attorney-turned-crime writer Ferdinand Von Schirach has two really good and surprising books of short stories, CRIME/GUILT and THE COLLINI CASE.

4) The cover of Denis Johnson‚Äôs very fun NOBODY MOVE is not made for reading in public, which makes it perfect for quarantine reading.

5) I have rarely found a book as creative and entertaining as BJ Novak‚Äôs (@bjnovak) ONE MORE THING.

And then, lastly, literally anything by Christopher Buckley, though both BOOMSDAY and THEY EAT PUPPIES DON‚ÄôT THEY seem to have special relevance now.

March 28, 2020: Edition #13 (The Amazing World Around Us)

Weeks ago, my friend @nicco sent me Robert MacFarland‚Äôs UNDERLAND, about the world under our feet, saying it ‚Äúenthralled‚Äù him. I‚Äôm reading it now and agree‚Äîso tonight‚Äôs theme is ‚Äúbooks about the amazing world around us,‚Äù from @CityLightsBooks in SF.

1) Susan Casey‚Äôs (@caseymaui) THE WAVE is a great study of the amazing power and mystery of the oceans.

2) Lewis Thomas‚Äôs classic LIVES OF A CELL opened my eyes to the wonder of science years ago.

3) Carlo Rovelli‚Äôs SEVEN BRIEF LESSONS ON PHYSICS literally blew my mind with its description of the interplay of heat and time, along other easy-to-understand lessons.

4) Alan Weisman‚Äôs WORLD WITHOUT US is a fascinating thought experiment about the footprint we‚Äôre leaving in the physical world.

5) And, lastly, literally anything by John McPhee is a gift in terms of curiosity and learning about the world around us. Pick up something like this reader if you‚Äôre looking to start: or dive into his book on ORANGES, yes, oranges.

March 29, 2020: Edition #14 (How Washington Really Works)

In recognition of DC finally agreeing on its $2T initial rescue legislation, tonight‚Äôs theme is my favorite books on how Washington really works. And tonight we‚Äôre back to supporting @Powells, which just announced it‚Äôs able to hire back 100 (!) of its staff due to a surge in online orders. So keep the orders coming! Save a job! Expand your mind! Buy a book! (koin.com/news/portland/‚Ä¶)

1) Evan Thomas and @WalterIsaacson‚Äòs classic THE WISE MEN is the definitive portrait of the tiny, elite, Ivy-educated circle who shaped the post-World War II world.

2) My friend (and editor!) Nick Thompson (@nxthompson) wrote a great book, THE HAWK AND THE DOVE, about two of the legends of the Cold War, George Kennan and Paul Nitze (a legend who also just so happened to be Nick‚Äôs grandfather).

3) John Bloom (@johnibloom) wrote what might seem like an esoteric tech history, about the rise and fall of the Iridium satellite network, ECCENTRIC ORBITS, which surprised me to be a detailed portrait of how lobbying shapes Washington behind-the-scenes.

4) And then two memoirs by two of the DC‚Äôs most critical eyes, Katharine Graham‚Äôs LIVING HISTORY and Meg Greenfield‚Äôs WASHINGTON.

5) One of the most classic inside-the-sausage-making tales of Washington is SHOWDOWN AT GUCCI GULCH, about how the Reagan era tax bill came to be, by @alansmurray and Jeffrey Birnbaum.

6) Plus one bonus, fun read, that‚Äôs all-too-true‚Äîthe book that spawned a saying and a thousand knowing-glances, Mark Leibovich‚Äôs (@MarkLeibovich) THIS TOWN.

March 30, 2020: Edition #15 (On Invention)

As we enter a third week of quarantine and #GMGReads‚Äîand the world races to figure out a vaccine so we can reemerge‚Äîhere are my favorite books about inventions. @sarvay has suggested @FountainBkstore in Richmond, so that‚Äôs who I‚Äôm featuring tonight. Buy a book! Save a job!

1) Dava Sobel‚Äôs LONGITUDE remains one of the most interesting books I‚Äôve ever read, a tale of a leap of logic and invention that seems so commonplace we forget how long it stymied humankind.

2) Jacob Soll‚Äôs RECKONING, a surprisingly interesting history of accounting (yes, accounting!), will convince you that double-entry bookkeeping is one of the most important inventions of all time.

3) Richard Rhodes‚Äôs THE MAKING OF THE ATOMIC BOMB is a tour du force of physics, history, and narrative reporting.

4) Annie Jacobsen‚Äôs (@AnnieJacobsen) OPERATION PAPERCLIP, the story of how Nazi scientists with horrible pasts helped the US win the space race, will leave you wondering whether the moral trade-offs were worth it.

5) Last summer, I chanced into reading David McCullough‚Äôs WRIGHT BROTHERS and found myself amazed at how much of the story of flight I didn‚Äôt know (France was really that important?!!?)

March 31, 2020: Edition #16 (On Emotions and Behavior)

I think everyone is feeling a lot of anxiety and uncertainty right now, so tonight I want to feature interesting books about human emotions and behavior. @c18913 suggested featuring @farleys in PA, so that‚Äôs your indie of the night!

1) Dr. Kay Redfield Jamison‚Äôs EXUBERANCE is just a great read about how passion plays out in the world.

2) No matter how much or little anxiety you may have in your regular life, you‚Äôll enjoy the tour offered by Scott Stossel (@SStossel) in MY AGE OF ANXIETY.

3) Eric Felten‚Äôs (@ETFelten) LOYALTY: THE VEXING VIRTUE explores something that‚Äôs easy to give, but hard to find in life.

4) Morra Aarons-Mele‚Äôs (morraam) HIDING IN THE BATHROOM offers an introvert‚Äôs guide to getting out in the world and helped shape my understanding of my own work patterns.

5) Annie Duke‚Äôs THINKING IN BETS, a guide written by a professional poker player, was a fascinating tour of how to be comfortable with uncertainty.

April 1, 2020: Edition #17 (Presidential Biographies)

Tonight, in honor of a @WIRED essay I wrote yesterday about leadership in a time of crisis, I thought I‚Äôd feature some of my favorite presidential biographies (not including Lincoln or Washington‚Äîthey‚Äôll be future lists on their own).

1) Two biographies of FDR, HW Brands‚Äô TRAITOR TO HIS CLASS and then Doris Kearns Goodwin‚Äôs NO ORDINARY TIME, about FDR and Eleanor together.

2) Ron Chernow‚Äôs GRANT is an obvious masterpiece‚Äîit‚Äôs so, so good‚Äîbut if you really want to understand Grant‚Äôs place in US history, you should read Joan Waugh‚Äôs US GRANT: AMERICAN HERO, AMERICAN MYTH.

3) Writing about presidents in near real-time is hard, but two writers who have done it well are John Harris (@harrispolitico) with his book on Clinton, THE SURVIVOR, and then Lou Cannon, who wrote ROLE OF A LIFETIME about Reagan.

4) Evan Thomas‚Äôs IKE‚ÄôS BLUFF will make a strong case that Eisenhower deserves far more greatness in our presidential pantheon than we typically give him.

5) And of course everything Robert Caro has written about LBJ ‚Äî each volume of which is fascinating and which together serve as the best portrait we‚Äôve ever gotten of a president. Start here with PATH TO POWER.

April 2, 2020: Edition #18 (Oral Histories)

I‚Äôm interviewing for my @WIRED living oral history of the Covid-19 pandemic‚Äîa new chapter publishes tomorrow!‚Äîwhich has me thinking about translating spoken words to printed words. Tonight, we‚Äôre featuring @onemorepagebooks & my five favorite oral histories, with a little twist.

1) The best oral history I‚Äôve ever come across is actually fictional: Max Brooks (@maxbrooksauthor) WORLD WAR Z, about the zombie apocalypse. I‚Äôve given it over the years to several writers to help them learn the oral history form.

2) George Saunders‚Äô LINCOLN IN THE BARDO, another fictional oral history, might be the best book I‚Äôve ever read. I wish I could read this book again for the 1st time. I spent a lot of time while writing ONLY PLANE IN THE SKY thinking about Saunders‚Äô craft.

3) If you‚Äôve never read Studs Terkel before, you‚Äôre missing out on one of the quintessential American writers, telling a quintessential American story. Start with WORKING, but he‚Äôs also done THE GOOD WAR, HARD TIMES, and others.

4) Svetlana Alexievich won the Nobel Prize in Literature for her collected stories of Russian voices. I‚Äôve read SECONDHAND TIME, about the end of the Soviet Union, and heard great things about THE UNWOMANLY FACE OF WAR.

5) If you liked the movie ‚Äú1917‚Äù or ‚ÄúThey Shall Not Grow Old,‚Äù you should pick up Peter Englund‚Äôs THE BEAUTY AND THE SORROW, an ‚Äúintimate history‚Äù of the First World War.

April 3, 2020: Edition #19 (Easy-to-Devour Nonfiction)

We did it! It‚Äôs Friday! Time to try to kick back and relax with some more light reading‚Äîtonight‚Äôs #GMGReads theme is just good, easy-to-devour narrative nonfiction.

1) Mark Bowden‚Äôs best known for BLACK HAWK DOWN, but if you watched ‚ÄúNarcos,‚Äù you should read the real tale of KILLING PABLO.

2) I didn‚Äôt get around to reading John Carreyrou‚Äôs (@JohnCarreyrou) BAD BLOOD, about Elizabeth Holmes and the fall of Theranos, until this winter, but it‚Äôs just as good as everyone says.

3) Candace Millard‚Äôs DESTINY OF THE REPUBLIC is the book you never knew you wanted to read about James A. Garfield.
